subject: Travel
title: The Terracotta Army Surprise
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Terracotta Army Surprise usable.

hook.text: In 1974, farmers digging a well in China found a clay soldier. Behind it stood 8,000 more.

buildup.text: Emperor Qin Shi Huang built the army to protect him in the afterlife. Each soldier has a unique face.

discovery.text: The soldiers were originally painted in bright colors. Exposure to air made the paint vanish within minutes.

twist.text: The emperor's actual tomb nearby remains sealed. Ancient texts say it contains rivers of liquid mercury.

climax.text: Soil tests confirm high mercury levels around the tomb. Scientists fear opening it would destroy the contents.

punchline.text: The greatest treasure may be the one we never open.

quiz.question: Why hasn't the emperor's tomb been opened?
options: Mercury contamination could destroy its contents
No one has found the entrance
